I'm just beggining to watch this course, but from something she said in the previous video, I think she means that in uncharged atoms, 3d orbitals have higher energy than the 4s ones, so it's the 4s ones that will be filled first, but when they are occupied, it's the other way round (the 3d have lower energy), so the 4s electrons will leave the atoms first. I.e., when you are "unfilling" an atom to see which electrons leave first, it's the 4s orbital ones rather than the 3d ones.

Plenty, electronic spectroscopy for example, it's math and science, the concept of IE is real, not just a theory. Nowadays Electronic structure theory can make accurate predictions, consistent with experimental data, or even crudely via Koopmans' theorem.   No one doubts the concept of ionization energy in science, it's old hat and first discovered around 1869.. The photo electric effect also involves ionisation, this was also verified by experiment.

The following textbook was used when this course was taught on the MIT campus:   Atkins, Peter William, and Loretta Jones. Chemical Principles: The Quest for Insight. 5th ed. Macmillan, 2010. I think you are confusing  ''affinity' with  ''the change in energy''. Delta E=The change in energy of the atom when an electron is added. Electron Affinity= minus (Delta E ).
